*Dynamic Filtering*
Consider the dashboard called Hierarchy as shown in the image.

_*Problem*_
I have 3 managers with userID: manager-1, manager-2, manager-3
When manager-1 logs in then he/she should see only rows where manager_id=1

Currently I am achieving this by using the Row Level security feature by setting the clause value as `manager_id = 1`

The issue with this is that is if 10k managers, I will need to do this 10,000 times.

_*Desired Solution*_
Is there a way in which I can use a function like `manager_id = get_manager_id()`
that captures the managers user name or some identifier then does the RLS based on the condition match.
for the other stuf I think having workers in a separate docker and stuff wouldn't be a problem, I'm eager to hear from Craig :slightly_smiling_face: I 'll check xvfb license

Hello, everyone! I'd like to be able to include an interactive filter box to exclude selections (instead of include, which is the default behavior). Is this possible?

*Related filters for filter-box*
Say my table has
```Group--SubGroup
A--aa1
A-aa2
B-bb1
B--bb2```
Filters on the Dashboard are:
• Group
• SubGroup
If, Group = A then dashboard renders values = aa1 & aa2, which is great
However,
SubGroup filter still shows all values, ie, aa1,aa2,bb1,bb2.

What I would like is,
if, Group = A, then SubGroup=aa1, aa2

Is there a way to currently do this?
Is there the equivalent of the query log for charts ? I'm particularly looking for logs on errors or timeouts (to identify user experience issues coming from the backend)

*Hi all,* 
*Preset is planning to conduct a series of user interviews/surveys to collect user feedback on Superset global navigation.* (Global Navigation Also called: main navigation, primary navigation, main nav. ) Global navigation represents the top-level pages of a site’s structure—or the pages below the home page. Optimized global navigation in Superset will support a variety of user tasks and modes of information seeking, including known-item seeking, exploration, and even re-finding.

The goal of this User Interview is to understand better how users currently navigate and find content in Superset. At a high level, we want to understand what users are trying to accomplish, how they do this, and what could be improved.

*We would like to work with voluntary users for a 20-30 minute session next week. Please let us know if you are interested. Thank you!! <#C0195GT7S1Y|user-interviews>*

Hey :wave: <@U01877YKTPB> as a heads up, it can be hard to debug connection issues in Superset since there’s many possible reasons!  Here’s my checklist when I can’t get a new data source connected:

• Is the python connector / library actually installed? You’ll want to open the shell within the right docker container (I don’t have the name handy unfortunately), fire up a python shell and confirm you can import that library.
• If the library imported fine, I’d confirm that you can connect to your data store from the library itself. You’ll probably need to pull up the docs / github page for that library to look up the connection insttuctions
• Do the logs (either backend or frontend in the browser console) show anything useful for you? I run superset within docker in non-detached mode so I can get that full log dump right to my face when I run into issues!
Let me know if any of these helped at all / when if you’ve tried these :slightly_smiling_face:

Hi all, I tried to use Jinja to create a query template similar to this and publish it as sql lab datasource:
```select 
customer_first_name 
from analytics.lead_names
WHERE 1=1
{% set f_name = filter_values('customer_first_name') %}
 {% if f_name %}
and customer_first_name in ( {{ "'" + "','".join(f_name ) + "'" }} )
{% endif %}```
I created a chart that utilizes the above datasource and added it in a dashboard together with a Filter box.
Even though the values from the Filter box are passed to the above template correctly, I noticed that the final query encapsulates the above query and adds an additional where clause, as shown below
Am I doing something wrong or is there a way not to have an extra where clause on the final query?
```SELECT
customer_first_name AS customer_first_name 
FROM
(
  select
    customer_first_name
  from
    analytics.lead_names
  WHERE
    1=1
    and customer_first_name in ('Anastasia')
)
AS expr_qry
WHERE customer_first_name IN ('Anastasia')
LIMIT 1000```

*Update the ab_user table of Superset SQLite*

I currently maintain user information of my application system on a Postgres backend. I want to push this data to the SQLite `ab_user` table that Superset uses.

What is the best way to do this?

Something like this will not work since SQLite does not support SHA.
```INSERT INTO ab_user (id,first_name,last_name,username,password,active,email) SELECT (3,'kafka','user', 'kafka-user',SHA('test',256),1,'kafka-user@gmail');```

Hi everyone! I\u2019m Ville, living in Helsinki, Finland. I work for Preset and have been contributing to Superset for a few years, lately as a committer and PMC member. Thanks for the comment <@UFG3USN8K> :slightly_smiling_face:

• Regard your first bullet, when you write Permission model, it is little bit confusing, I’m not sure if you mean Security models, Permission model or resource/view menu model.
• Regard the auto CRUD, the implementation should not change the design. In java, spring have that ability, and there is spring for python so I’m sure a solution for it will be found, worst case we have to implement dynamic association by join.
• Regard db constraint - if you can write a constraint for it at DB level (worst case, it can be done by trigger), it should be written at SQLAlchemy level. if there is a feature we can do at DB level but not at SQLAlchemy level, we can announce of missing feature and starting with SQLAlchemy contribution.
• Regard your second bullet - yes - if it a little bit confusing, we can think of can_access.dashboard* or dashboard[all] , it doesn’t really matter.
• third bullet - we agree with you, and I have ideas how to do it more efficiently then create a role for one user “dashboad_x_owner_role” but let’s focus on it later.
• Your first note - true, that what we think too.

Performance Question:
Our Superset performance has significantly slowed over the past 4-6 weeks and I'm wondering if the new version will help resolve this issue.

Symptoms:
• Loading the dashboard initially performs well
• Filtering and drilling around has really slow response time, so slow that some of the charts just time out and don't render at all
Background:
• We are on the previous version of Superset.
• Changes on our end include modeling a new star schema for reporting and adding some new data, but not a lot. Maybe 10-20% increase in data size since when we had good performance. 
• We've tested performance directly on the database, and it seems the data is pulled on the initial dashboard opening but not for filtering so it seems the performance issue resides in Superset itself.
What about the latest release of Superset?
• We could stand up a new instance with the latest version and test if performance improves, but I'm not sure it will help our circumstance if there haven't been specific performance improvements made to this version.
Would an upgrade improve performance?
What else should we be considering?

<@U019BCGD0QY> and <@U010L66PJ6N> Thank you for your valuable comments!
Rolling back a bit I like option 1 more, it's probably more flexible and future proof. Yet a case can still be made for a more simpler model using option 2 (M-M directly from Role).
Having said that, here's some further questions on option 1 including your suggestions
• I would prefer to follow the path of least FAB model overriding. That's why I chose to just change the `ViewMenu` model. Also using `obj_type` , `obj_id` is interesting but auto MVC CRUD or auto API CRUD has no way to infer the relation between objects ( probably not a show stopper since we can always custom develop the UI and backend ), but we would loose free constraint integrity from the DB also. So 2.a but using normal SQLAlchemy relations
• 4.b do you mean using `can_access.dashboard` to refer to a permission that allows to access all dashboards?
• By adding a `can_edit` or `can_read_write` permission, we could potentially drop the `owners` concept. I imagine that it's not easy to maintain a list of specific users for each dashboard. Probably better to group users with roles that gives them permission to edit (owners). (We add complexity and also remove complexity)
Note: Following this new structure we can have data access permissions and dashboard access permissions at the same time and still support the current logic.
Note: This is a big change, that I think we should eventually make, would love to ear from <@U7HPM7JHL> and <@UH0UPCJVD>

<@U01690HA6E8> I don't advise using a filesystem cache if this is a production system. You need to setup a result's cache and would advise to use celery workers also
Here's an example for setting up celery and a results cache:
```from werkzeug.contrib.cache import RedisCache

...

class CeleryConfig(object):
    BROKER_URL = "<redis://localhost:6379/0>"
    CELERY_IMPORTS = ("superset.sql_lab", "superset.tasks")
    CELERY_RESULT_BACKEND = "<redis://localhost:6379/0>"
    CELERYD_PREFETCH_MULTIPLIER = 10
    CELERY_ACKS_LATE = True

CELERY_CONFIG = CeleryConfig

RESULTS_BACKEND = RedisCache(host='localhost', port=6379, key_prefix='superset_results')```

My implementation suggestions as adjusted to design sections
1. keep the current model
2. two choices:
    a. add another table “resource” with object id and object type, as migrations step current FAB permission will be referenced to view_menu table
    b. alter the view menu table to have “object type” and object id.  current FAB permission  object type will be “view_menu”
3. add new permission as “ALL” or “read-write”
4. two choices:
    a. add another table “resource_types” with the rows [“dashboard”, ’view”, “chart”, …. ] then you can reference to that table as “all” of that resource. for specific drilled resource reference to it (reference to dashboard table)
   b. string manipulations and drilled down will be implemented by “dot”

Other issues I think should be mentioned
• The enforcement process of answer the question does the user have permission to resource? should not be distinguished by the resource type
• for making things more simple and clean, there is no need to create duplicate permissions type for specific resources - for example no need “can access all datasources” and “can access all dashboards” and “can access” to specific dashboard.
       the permission “read/access” can be used together for almost all the resources
• It is so complicated and contrary to “separation of concerns” principle when specific resource type is mentioned in the security manager
Now we can move on how to implement it ( and refactor current code)

Hello Superset community <!channel>: sorry for the @ channel notification bomb :bomb: , but we've made some big changes to this Slack channel that I want to make sure you all know. We made some new channels and archived old ones that are inactive/confusing, We hope you'll start using them, so we can cut down the noise in general channel and make this experience more welcoming and useful for all! Some highlights below :point_down:

1. Introduce yourself in <#C015WAR4SDV|introductions>! :smile:

2. If you haven't done so already: Please change your display name to: First Name + Last Name (full or 1st letter) + Company / Org you're involved with. To help out your fellow community members, we request that you add your role to the "What I Do" field in your Slack profile.

3.  Join new channel that catches your eyes! :eyes:
- New users are automatically added to <#C015WAR4SDV|introductions>, <#C014QMBQEU8|announcements>, <#CT43EC37H|newsletter>, <#C0170U650CQ|beginners>, <#C0169MXN3HB|community-feedback>, <#CH307T4JG|apache-releases>
- <#C0170U650CQ|beginners>: a kind, warm place to get your beginner questions answered.
- <#C016B3LG5B4|dashboards>: where all the cool data analysts hang out and talk about visualizations, dashboards, etc. :chart_with_upwards_trend:
- <#C014LS99C1K|contributing>: if you want to learn more about how to contribute to the Superset project.
- <#C0169MXN3HB|community-feedback>: if you have feedback on the community itself.
- Some other good ones: <#C016H8VDQUU|jobs> (Superset skills are valuable! :moneybag:), <#C015WAZL0KH|support> (installation/upgrading/etc. questions), <#C015WB6GUHM|feature-requests>

4. Familiarize yourself with our Slack community guidelines <<https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset#slack-community-guidelines>>. We want to maintain a warm and friendly community feel!

<@U018H0JE06M> hi there, Superset can’t query external data API’s directly. Superset has to work with a supported database or data engine (<https://superset.incubator.apache.org/installation.html#database-dependencies>). This means that you need to find a way to fetch data out of the API and store it in a supported database / data engine. Some options:

• Build a little Python pipeline that will query the data API, flatten the data to something tabular / relational, and upload that data to a supported data source - <https://superset.incubator.apache.org/installation.html#database-dependencies> - and set up Superset so it can talk to that database / data engine.
• For more robust solutions, you may want to work with an devops / infrastructure to stand up a workflow scheduler like Apache Airflow (<https://airflow.apache.org/>) to regularly ping this API and store it in a database of some kind that Superset can talk to.
*Either way, Superset is just a thin layer above your database / data engine. So there’s no way around the reality that you need to find a way to extract data out of an API and store it in a compatible data source.*

so what we know now:
1. There are several operations on each resource as Amit said (read/access, edit/update. delete/remove, grantor)
2. Resource can be drilled down (Dashboard, Chat and so on but can be drill down to specific dashboard)
3. There are “Operators” who can have permission to do several (or all) operation on same resource
4. There are “Operators” who can have same permission for all the drilled down resource - in simple words - I have permission to all dashboards or simply to “dashboard” or specific resource
5. There are group of operators who have common permissions (Role)
6. There are scenarios which a grantor operator would like to grant permission to other players 
7. There are scenarios (flows) for handle it, require several permissions for several different resources - example fetching a specific dashboard - I need an access permission for “GET DASHBOARD” resource + read permission for the specific dashboard

Hey everyone! We met with AirBnB today in discussion of SIP-45. Here is the summary:

*Identified UX problems:*
• When filters are not applied properly, dashboard consumers need to be alerted to the fact that they can not trust the data being presented.
• When filters are not applied properly, dashboard creators need to know a chart is incompatible so they can remove it from the filter scope.
• Filter scopes are often over-applied because Dashboard creators currently find it a hassle to apply filter scopes
*Technical Considerations:*
• SIP-45 option #1 has possible performance concerns with checking filter eligibility up front.
*Action Item(s):*
• Preset design team will propose an alternative design for strategy #2 from SIP-45
• AirBnB to investigate performance of validating filter eligibility (how long for many filters / complex data)
Let me know if I should add anything.

*<!here>* I kicked off the graduation process for Superset at the Apache Software Foundation yesterday!
```to:dev@

Hi all!

Over the past few months/years, the Apache Superset community has met all
the requirements to graduate from the Apache Incubator. Given that, I
believe we are ready for graduation and I'm excited to kick off the process
with a community vote at this time.

For the record, we have been incubating since 2017-05-02, have had 8
official Apache-approved releases, and have voted in 20 PMC members and 11
committers. See our Incubation Status File for more details:
<https://incubator.apache.org/projects/superset.html>

For reference, you can find out everything you need to know about the
graduation requirements and process here:
<https://incubator.apache.org/guides/graduation.html>

Consider this an implicit +1 from me.

Cheers!

Max```

Hey AirBnB team, I'm currently defining an incompatible filter as a filter that meets one of the following conditions:
• The filter is for a column that isn't present on the data-set
• The filter is for a column on the dataset, but the value type doesn't match
• The filter causes the query to crash for some other reason

<@U0108GJRR0F> sorry to hear! Right off the bat, it looks like SQLAlchemy (which is how superset talks to databases) is reporting that MySQL isn’t happy about all the connections Superset is making to it. Not using the async workers or caching functionality in Superset could cause this.

Other potentially useful context:

• Where are you running this? Locally? Cloud? Home-grown raspberry pi cluster?
• How are you running this? Natively? Within Docker? Within Kubernetes? 
• What databases / data sources are you using? A RDBMS like Postgres? A data engine like Athena / Presto / Hive / Dremio?
• How many charts are in this dashboard?

is superset just a visualization dashboard...i mean i can write SQL queries against DB sources, get the results and visualize those results? just comparing it with Apache kylin which is also an OLAP cube based engine that works on the SQL data to speed up queries...or Apache Druid which does similar but in a different way

<@USCL3SULS> you\u2019re correct that Superset has no ingest / compute layer. Superset sits atop your existing databases / data infrastructure and has a minimal + optional caching layer to help with some speedups (e.g. if 1k people in a company are loading the same charts / dashboards, no need to do a roundtrip to your database each time if nothing\u2019s changed!)

Ok, so I found out, that it was an authentification problem. Our databases use the latest mysql and as described <https://github.com/passbolt/passbolt_docker/issues/103|here> we needed to switch to using the native password auth method with ``ALTER USER 'username'@'ip_address' IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'password';`` . Since Metabase did not need that, I assume that they can support newer versions of MySQL? Maybe something to look into.

As some of you may know, we’ve been eager to migrate our charts over to Apache ECharts [<https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/10418|SIP-50>]. Echarts offers a wide array of but consistent data visualization types. It is actively maintained by a vibrant community, it’s very mature, and has excellent extensibility. The entire migration process will take some time and we want your input on which charts Superset should consider porting over first or including in Superset 1.0.
<https://forms.gle/4pvoLqgYrbsgzDxW6> This survey will only take you less than 2 mins to complete ~:pray:
If you have interest in participating in the engineering effort, let us know, and we’ll try to distribute the work and help define best-practices. <#C0195GT7S1Y|product_feedback>
If you are interested in getting to know more about or contribute to ECharts, please visit <https://echarts.apache.org/en/index.html>, or reach out to <@U018116Q89F>

Accordingly to SuperSet, it means "Failed to exchange authorization code for Access Token" .  Here is our configuration so far:

```OAUTH_PROVIDERS = [
    {   'name':'auth0',
        'token_key':'access_token', # Name of the token in the response of access_token_url
        'icon':'fa-address-card',   # Icon for the provider
        'remote_app': {
            'consumer_key': 'DXRewxxxxxxxxxxxUFIVG',  # Client Id (Identify Superset application)
            'consumer_secret': 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx', # Secret for this Client Id (Identify Superset application)
            'request_token_params':{
                'scope': 'openid email profile',               # Scope for the Authorization
                'audience': '<https://dev-xxxxxx.au.auth0.com/api/v2/>'
            },
            'access_token_method':'POST',    # HTTP Method to call access_token_url
            'base_url': '',
            'access_token_url': '<https://dev-xxxxx.au.auth0.com/oauth/token>',
            'authorize_url': '<https://dev-xxxxxx.au.auth0.com/authorize>',
            'client_id': 'DXRewxxxxxxxxxxxUFIVG'
        }```

Hey all! Just wanted to say thanks for all the awesome work being put into Superset! It's a really great tool. We've been using it for the past 6 months as one of the main entry points into our warehouse. We have just over 100 users using it atm. Our stack is mainly Druid, Presto, and MySQL. My feedback on superset is definitely positive, however like anything, it for sure has it's pain points. Just figured I'd share some of them that we face:

• Large CSV dumps.  Nothing bothers me more than when a user complains about it as most of the time a user wants to download a CSV bigger than even excel can even open, however I've grown to understand this need a bit more from users. Often times, there's integrations someone from marketing, accounting, etc needs to run to push to an SFTP bucket or something equivalent, and although they likely can't even open the files themselves, sometimes these are for POC's for some integration a team is looking to test out. I totally understand the limitation that superset renders the results in the browser, however just sharing the pain point there.
• Users leaving auto refreshing dashboards on. It's common for a user to have an auto refreshing dashboard open, leave their browser window open, and have it run a really complex Presto query every 10 seconds. This adds a lot of load onto our Presto cluster or other parts of the stack, and we end up having to reach out to users to close their browser windows. Ideally, there's something in the FE that stops an auto refreshing dashboard from running after X time (might be a good administrator setting)
• Presto doesn't show catalogs or schemas in SQL lab. It's pretty confusing to explain to users how to query presto via superset when they can't see the catalogs themselves (you can tell them to run `show catalogs` but this is hard to explain to a lot of people). I might be missing a setting or something for this, and if there's something I don't know on this, would love to know how I can add this (our presto cluster is connected to 6 different sources)
I should also add that we have found this behavior only on one table at the moment, but we cannot trust the other RLS filters anymore

<@U7HPM7JHL> The biggest block at the moment is assuaging concern about our periodic meetings. I think the biggest things I want to point out is that:
1. Showing the company in the notes isn't a _bad thing._ It doesn't lend importance to the org, but tracks involvement, in service of continuing to maintain a diverse PPMC going forward
2. The meeting isn't a secret by any means. There are in fact *88* people on the calendar event, and more are welcome!
3. Synchronous meetings have a value to them that's not easily replaced by email. Discussions happen around technical work taking place on certain PRs or other work. Asking and answering questions conversationally is often quite effective. If things are at all contentious, they're brought back to the whole community as a SIP, which has happened numerous times.

Question about Dashboards: all the charts in my dashboard share some common columns. Time is the obvious one, but also other things. For example, suppose one chart is server CPU, and another is server memory, for hundreds of servers.\nIs it possible to filter all charts in a Dashboard? For example, to make all charts show the last 5 minutes, or the last day? Or, to make all charts show only a particular server, or a set of servers like `hostname like 'foo%'`?

<https://superset.apache.org/docs/frequently-asked-questions>

By default, the filtering will be applied to all the slices that are built on top of a datasource that shares the column name that the filter is based on. It’s also a requirement for that column to be checked as “filterable” in the column tab of the table editor.

Hope this help

*Admin User when using Authentication Provider*
When using
```    AUTH_DB,
    AUTH_LDAP,
    AUTH_OAUTH,
    AUTH_OID,
    AUTH_REMOTE_USER```
Only users registered with the Authentication service provider can login.

Drawback:
If we deploy Superset for a client and are required to be an Admin, we have to ask them to create a user within their auth system. Some client's user creation protocols don't all for such kind of users to be created.

1) In our org we will have hundreds of dashboards that will be based on the same datasource
Therefore there is no way to manage dashboard access for specific dashboards for specific users 

2), we want to make sure that /dashboard/(<Id>/<slug>)  is also enforcing access . Currently anyone can access any dashboard by just changing the url.
Sometimes there is PII on the dashboard itself like markup or an iframe so it still expose something on the dashboard which is problematic to some of our clients 

<@UM4AW481K>
I think it is useful to understand what problem you are trying to solve and be crispy clear about that. It will help with choosing the approach.

RUN yum install -y unixODBC unixODBC-devel

## install latest dremio odbc driver
RUN yum install -y <https://download.dremio.com/odbc-driver/dremio-odbc-LATEST.x86_64.rpm>

## install superset
RUN pip3 install apache-superset sqlalchemy_dremio

## run superset_config.py copy
RUN echo $PYTHONPATH
RUN echo $PATH
COPY superset_config.py /usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/superset/superset_config.py

## upgrade superset database to latest
RUN export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 && superset db upgrade

## initialize superset
RUN export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 && superset init

## list directories
RUN echo $(ls)
RUN echo $(ls /usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/superset/)
RUN echo $(ls /home/)

## create default admin user
RUN export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 && \n    export FLASK_APP=superset && \n    flask fab create-admin --username admin --firstname admin --lastname admin --email admin@admin --password admin

EXPOSE 8088

CMD ["gunicorn", "-w", "2", "-b", "0.0.0.0:8088", "--timeout", "120", "--limit-request-line", "0", "--limit-request-field_size", "0", "<http://superset.app:create_app()|superset.app:create_app()>", "superset", "run"]```

<@U014E6V0P8E> has joined the channel
<@U010L66PJ6N> set the channel topic: This channel was created in order to get a collective discussion on how what should be the approach for dashboard security?

<@UFG3USN8K>  thanks for the feedback
let’s start by few definitions:
1. data objects = (Dashboard, chart, dataset, database and etc’)
2. data objects access= permission to *access* the specific data object
3. data objects edit= permission to *edit* the specific data object
4. data objects delete= permission to *delete* the specific data object
5. data objects grant= permission to *grant access* the specific data object
6. data objects owner = has permissions to access/edit/delete/grant access those data objects

if complexity is the issue here so we should also consider the following topics when thinking about revamping:
1. how should we manage `specific` data objects permissions as mentioned in the above definitions (example: edit permission to dashboard 34)
2. how should we support all data objects access  ( like all datasources access) that easily allowing granting all data objects access for a specific type of data( Dashboard, dataset and etc’) ?

could you update the 2 options you described accordingly?
<@U019BCGD0QY> has joined the channel
Or a simple many to many directly from\u00a0`Role`\u00a0to datasets, database, dashboards, etc...

In my view, I think that the SIP looks good, but yes I get concerned on 2 points:
• Possible overly complex logic, the feature flag sort of solves this, but still the complexity lives on the code
• Adding more logic based on permissions using special strings `VIEW_NAME_FORMAT = "dashboard.[{obj.dashboard_title}](id:{obj.id})"` is not ideal
So this could be a good time to stop and revamp our security around data access and possibly include charts and dashboards access to the mix. One possible path forward could be to extend FAB's current security models and or create a new Role model type (DataAcessRole or SupersetRole) or just extend the Permission class and add fks to specific objects, example:
I've been talking with <@U7HPM7JHL> about this, and a possible path forward could imply a revamp on how security is done for data access and dashboards. I'll leave some possible ideas here tomorrow

<@UH0UPCJVD>
This is the was <@UFG3USN8K> is working on which is basically a filter for favourites <https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/11083|https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/11083>

This is the same way we implements the dashboard level access single responsibility of filters in the filters.py file
I\u2019d love to hear <@UFG3USN8K>\u2019s thoughts on how this can be implemented in a way that doesn\u2019t introduce unnecessary complexity.

My main concern is that we should be careful not not to make an already complex and loaded permission model even more complex than it currently is. One major risk I see is if we have multiple overlapping permission structures, it can become difficult to resolve situations where customers either see or don\u2019t see the data that they need.

I have seen multiple instances in a previous role where stakeholders from different organisations wanted to use the same datasource but wanted to restrict dashboard access, in part to not expose how the metrics and how they were using the data. So I do understand where Amit & team\u2019s requirement is coming from.
I'll add all the relevant context to the SIP itself

Beside that dashboard level access is a repeated requirement over years now in superset in many issues mentioned before mine 
I'm for sure not alone in this depending only on data source access doesn't seems sufficient enough when involving external clients

Also think about the following overhead :
Dashboard A consists of a single datasource A and there there hundreds of users watching it 
The. After a while the dashboard get edited with an additional datasource.
Then immediately all those hundreds of users loose accesss to the dashboard .
If it was dashboard level access it won't ever happen

It is not that no data source existing on Dashboard is that the dashboard specific endpoint /view are not being enforced by any security measure and there might by PII even when data sources are not available
e.g. if there will be fake datasource behind markdown / iframe + row level security - would it solve the problem ?
I have skimmed through the SIP and I definitely lack the context on the problem you are solving & what are the blockers in current implementation

usually I approach problems like this in such order:
• understand the scope of the problem & user use cases
• figure out if it can be achieved in current architecture & primitives with the small tweaks
• if not -> what is a good technical solution & alternatives
